title: 114_hr6510
content: The Act may be cited as the "Save the Children Act of 2016". Congress expresses its sense. The "Save the Children Act of 2016" expresses Congress's sense that thousands of Syrian children in refugee camps face a humanitarian crisis due to the civil war violence. The Act calls for the temporary relocation and care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees in the United States over three years. The Act calls for the relocation of up to 25,000 young Syrian child refugees to the United States over three years. Efforts should be made to reunite or relocate them back to Syria once the civil war violence decreases. The Save the Children Program is established under Section 3 of the Act to relocate young Syrian child refugees to the United States with efforts to reunite or relocate them back to Syria once the civil war violence decreases. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. A grace period of six months is given before visas expire to reunify children with their families. Only children with established guardians present or orphaned are eligible for visas. An Office of Coordination is established in the Office of Refugee. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. A Coordinator is established in the Office of Refugee Resettlement to oversee the program's operations in the United States. Additional personnel may be appointed by the Coordinator as needed. The Coordinator in the Office of Refugee Resettlement can appoint additional personnel with approved pay. Federal departments can detail personnel to assist the Coordinator. The Coordinator can utilize the staff and resources of the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services. The Coordinator in the Office of Refugee Resettlement can appoint additional personnel with approved pay and utilize the staff and resources of the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services to identify and resettle young minor children in the United States under the Program. The Coordinator in the Office of Refugee Resettlement works in accordance with relevant laws, international agreements, and US foreign policy and security interests. They collaborate with approved organizations and government authorities to implement the Program and assist those admitted. The Coordinator consults with key officials to ensure Program operations align with legal requirements, international agreements, and the goal of family reunification. The Program operations must comply with relevant laws, international agreements, US foreign policy, and domestic security interests. It will terminate six months after certification of reduced civil war violence and displaced Syria inhabitants. The Program will reunite minor children admitted to the US with their families after a substantial reduction in civil war violence and displaced Syria inhabitants. The Program may be suspended if deemed necessary for US foreign policy and domestic security interests. The Program may be suspended or terminated if the President determines it is necessary for US foreign policy and domestic security interests. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year to carry out the Program, with funds available from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act of 1962. A report detailing the Program's implementation must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program shall admit alien minor children aged three to ten under a temporary nonimmigrant visa until civil war violence in Syria substantially reduces. Preference is given to children already in custody of the US or its allies outside Syria. The Syrian Civil War Minor Child Protection Act of 2016 allows alien children aged three to ten, who are residents of Syria or displaced persons/refugees, to temporarily reside in the US under the Save the Children Program, until civil war violence in Syria significantly decreases. Aliens admitted to the US under the Save the Children Act of 2016 can stay until civil war violence in Syria significantly decreases, as certified by the Secretary of State, with a six-month grace period for reunification efforts.
